text: The explosion of AI over the past couple of years
has tipped the scales on a long developing paradigm shift.
Technology is no longer just another tool to support business objectives.
It's a fundamental driver of business value.
To maximize this value and join the AI revolution,
organizations need an IT foundation that's built intentionally.
Adopting a hybrid by design strategy.
The AI era holds great promise for unlocking new business opportunities
and driving efficiencies.
To fully capitalize on AI's potentials,
organizations need a solid Hybrid Cloud Foundation.
Yet many businesses are still grappling with transforming their legacy estate
and building the necessary foundation to foster that innovation.
Why is that?
Well, as organizations have evolved,
they have adopted technology in pockets
across various environments.
Now managing on premise, multiple clouds and even edge.
This has resulted in fragmentations and silos across the organization,
leading to a variety of issues.
Complex IT environments,
unrealized business use cases and outcomes,
cloud and technology sprawl,
overspending, the inability to scale.
And this is what we're defining as hybrid by default.
Now, there's no question hybrid cloud is the right choice for many organizations
looking to be competitive and leverage generative AI.
But to do so requires building an IT ecosystem
that is intentional, and consistent for business needs.
With that in place, organizations, they can harness the power of hybrid and AI
to achieve speed, flexibility and innovation.
What we are defining as hybrid by design.
Based on conversations with a wide range of companies,
we've seen five common patterns emerge in organizations
that operate a successful hybrid by design strategy.
One, they embrace a product centric mindset for enabling business needs.
Two, they build an intentional architecture for core competencies.
Three, they create a consistent development
and operational experience across their platforms.
Four, they empower their product teams.
And five, lastly, they harness the power of their data and scale generative AI.
Now, an intentionally design hybrid Cloud
provides that blueprint to more effectively harness these desired capabilities
so organizations can accelerate their transformation
and maximize their return on IT investments.
So how do we achieve this?
Well, we can break down the approach to a hybrid by design strategy
into three key transformation areas.
Product led by design,
integration by design
and technology by design.
The first transformation area, product led by design,
focuses on better business and IT alignment.
Aligning all of IT processes around the value to products and services
with purpose and consistency.
Positioning business products and services
as the primary driver for all of IT operations
with an intentionally designed operating model around
what brings the most value to your end customers.
It also provides operational and development consistency
for productivity and scale to meet the needs of the business
and those products and services.
The second transformation area, technology by design,
focuses on intentional architectural choices across the IT stack
that enable agility and innovation for your business needs,
as well as consistency across environments
to empower and scale your product teams.
It addresses that intentionality and consistency across AI platforms,
data platforms,
common application platforms and your infrastructure.
Maximizing the advantages of your technology
and focusing them for your business.
The last area, integration by design,
focuses on unifying your IT ecosystem.
Really, the glue between your people and your technology,
harmonizing systems and people across the architecture
to ensure a seamless data flow
and collaboration across the company.
So how do you prioritize these transformation areas and get started?
Well, successful organizations will start with their business objectives.
Is it cost savings?
Business growth?
Time to market?
New product development?
Or all four?
Every enterprise this situation demands different levels of capabilities
to address and to achieve these business objectives.
Organizations though, they have limited budgets and resources,
and so creating a prioritized roadmap is important to focus on
what brings your organization the most value.
As we break down each transformation area,
we can pinpoint the essential changes and priorities that align to your business objectives
and reprioritize your digital transformation.
Let's explore each.
In product led by design,
an organization needs to focus on capabilities like
product centricity.
Process and organization.
People and culture.
Platform operations.
While integration by design,
an organization needs to focus on things like their integration experience.
Human to machine integration.
Their integration platforms..
Machine to machine integration.
And in technology by design,
organizations need to focus on things like security and compliance.
Gen AI models and platforms.
Data sharing and governance.
Kubernetes and hosting platform.
And operating platform.
By always aligning to your business objectives,
you can determine which capabilities are most important
to achieve your desired outcomes.
Then you'll be better equipped to understand where you are now,
and where you need to aspire to be.
Simply put, executing an efficient and effective transformation
means looking tactically, holistically in business first,
which in turn will maximize your business outcomes.
AI, and specifically generative AI,
has become a critical puzzle piece in the success of this digital transformation journey.

cost management insight,
increase observability, enhanced security.

Cross stack security,
an enterprise wide data platform,
all of which a robust hybrid cloud platform can provide.
Hybrid cloud and AI have a symbiotic relationship

A shift of this scope is never comfortable.
With AI integration and adoption now an absolute mandate,
